metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin(Huailai station-automatic weather station-10m tower, 2018)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Meteorological elements of Huailai station between January 1 and December 31, 2017. The site (115.7880° E, 40.3491° N) was located on a maize surface, which is near Donghuayuan Town of Huailai city in Hebei Province. The elevation is 480 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (5 m, north), wind speed and direction profile (10 m, north), air pressure (in the box), rain gauge (10 m), four-component radiometer (5 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (5 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (-0.06 m), soil temperature profile (0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), and a TCAV averaging soil thermocouple probe (-0.02, -0.04 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m; RH_5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, and Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content), and average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2017-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Yang et al. (2015) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

Definition.Question: What does 'aerodynamic roughness length (z0m)' mean in the context of surface flux estimations?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. It is originally defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'analytical footprint model' in the context of estimating aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces?
Definition.Answer: An analytical footprint model is used to calculate and analyze the directional characteristics of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces, by considering the contribution of various surface components based on their spatial distribution and roughness characteristics.

Definition.Question: What is 'footprint weighting method' in relation to aggregating aerodynamic roughness length data?
Definition.Answer: The footprint weighting method is a technique used to aggregate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) data over a whole experimental field by considering the contributions of individual surface components, weighted by their influence on the observed area.

Comparison.Question: In terms of dataset content, how does the range of variables measured in the automatic meteorological station dataset at Huailai station compare to those involved in the Xiaotangshan Experiment?
Comparison.Answer: The automatic meteorological station dataset at Huailai station includes a wide range of variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, atmospheric pressure, precipitation, radiation components, and soil temperature and moisture at multiple depths. In contrast, the Xiaotangshan Experiment primarily focuses on measuring aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) and its relation to roughness element characteristics, which may involve fewer direct atmospheric and soil measurements but focus on wind profile and surface characteristics.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can data from multi-layer soil moisture and temperature sensors contribute to understanding the interaction between soil and atmospheric conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: Data from multi-layer soil moisture and temperature sensors provide insights into the thermal and moisture dynamics of the soil, which are crucial for understanding soil-atmosphere interactions. These interactions can influence surface energy balances, affecting local climate conditions and aiding in the calibration of land surface models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for quality control in meteorological data collection methods, particularly when dealing with data gaps or errors?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In meteorological data collection, quality control is necessary due to potential data gaps or errors caused by equipment malfunctions, such as those documented with the data collector and wind sensors, which lead to missing data for certain periods. Ensuring consistent data output and identifying physically implausible or out-of-range data points are crucial for maintaining data integrity.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to derive aerodynamic roughness length values from station observations in remote sensing and land surface models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Deriving aerodynamic roughness length values from station observations is challenging because it requires detailed wind profile measurements, which are not easily obtainable at local or regional scales. The variation of roughness length across different surfaces further complicates its estimation without extensive station data or parameterizations related to land surface properties.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a high-frequency data collection method, like a 30s sampling frequency, on the accuracy and completeness of meteorological datasets over an agricultural surface?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a high-frequency data collection method, such as a 30s sampling frequency, can significantly enhance the accuracy of meteorological datasets by capturing short-term fluctuations in environmental conditions. However, it also increases the volume of data, which may lead to challenges in storage and processing. Ensuring the completeness of the data is crucial, as missing data marked with placeholders like -6999 can impact analysis. High-frequency data can better capture transient meteorological events, thus improving the understanding of surface flux dynamics over agricultural surfaces like irrigated maize fields.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to ensure data quality control and uniform formatting in meteorological datasets collected using automated weather stations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Ensuring data quality control and uniform formatting is essential to maintain the reliability and accuracy of the dataset, facilitating its use for scientific analysis, model calibration, and comparison across different studies and geographical locations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in setting up an automatic weather station on a 10m tower for collecting multiscale surface flux and meteorological data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Setting up involves installing various sensors on the tower to measure factors like air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, atmospheric pressure, precipitation, radiation components, and soil parameters. Sensors are placed at specific heights and orientations, such as air temperature and humidity at 5m facing north, and soil probes at varying depths below the surface.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to aggregate and analyze aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) data over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The method involves calculating the z0m for each land surface component using characteristic parameters like vegetation height and leaf area index, and then aggregating these individual z0m values over the experimental field using a footprint weighting method to account for the spatial distribution and size of roughness elements.

Enablement.Question: What data processing and quality control methods enable the generation of reliable meteorological data from automatic weather stations in agricultural settings?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing and quality control methods include ensuring a complete dataset with 1440 data points per day, marking missing data with a specific indicator, removing duplicate records, eliminating data that exceed physical or instrumental limits, and standardizing the date and time format.

Enablement.Question: How do experimental setups and observation conditions, such as the installation height and location of sensors, enable accurate measurement of soil temperature and moisture profiles?
Enablement.Answer: The installation of soil temperature and moisture sensors at various depths (from 0 cm to 160 cm) and specific distances from the meteorological tower, in addition to the standardized positioning of sensors (such as the 10m tower for meteorological data), enables detailed profiling of soil conditions.

Enablement.Question: What observational and analytical approaches enable the estimation of aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces for remote sensing applications?
Enablement.Answer: The use of analytical footprint models, alongside wind profile measurements and roughness element characteristic factors like vegetation height and leaf area index, enables the estimation of aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces, as demonstrated in the Xiaotangshan Experiment.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to obtain aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) data for local or regional scales using only station observations?
Expectation.Answer: In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations because the traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why might data be insufficient for discussions on aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) parameterization in certain surface models?
Expectation.Answer: More data is needed for further discussions on the parameterization of z0m, as the current data might not be adequate to comprehensively relate z0m to roughness element characteristic factors across diverse surfaces.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using automatic weather stations at different heights, such as a 10m tower, for collecting comprehensive meteorological data in agricultural regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Automatic weather stations on structures like a 10m tower are effective in gathering detailed meteorological data across various parameters, including air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and soil characteristics. The comprehensive nature and high frequency of data collection (e.g., every 30 seconds with 10-minute outputs) provide a robust dataset for understanding atmospheric conditions in agricultural areas, though challenges like data gaps due to equipment failure must be managed.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges in ensuring the quality and completeness of meteorological datasets collected over extended periods?
Judgmental.Answer: Ensuring quality and completeness in meteorological datasets over extended periods involves challenges such as sensor malfunctions, data gaps due to equipment failures, and environmental influences affecting sensor accuracy. Rigorous data processing and quality control protocols, such as marking missing data and removing physically implausible values, are crucial in maintaining dataset integrity.

Judgmental.Question: How might the integration of aerodynamic roughness length calculations add value to existing meteorological datasets collected in agricultural areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating aerodynamic roughness length calculations into meteorological datasets can significantly enhance the understanding of surface-atmosphere exchanges in agricultural areas. It allows for a more nuanced characterization of surface roughness, influencing wind profiles and surface flux estimations, thereby improving the accuracy of models used in remote sensing and land surface studies.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how different land surface properties affect the aerodynamic roughness length in data collection methods for surface flux estimations.
Assertion.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is influenced by land surface properties such as vegetation height and leaf area index (LAI). These properties control wind turbulence as they describe the structure and spacing of roughness elements on the land surface, which in turn affects z0m. Parameterizations between z0m and land surface properties are used to estimate z0m over heterogeneous surfaces, especially when direct measurements are challenging.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure why the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces are important in observational data collection.
Assertion.Answer: The directional characteristics of z0m are important because z0m is direction-dependent due to the heterogeneity of roughness elements' size and spatial distribution in the source area, which varies with wind direction. Understanding these characteristics allows for more accurate parameterization of z0m in models, improving surface flux estimations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges of ensuring data quality and consistency in long-term meteorological observations at automated weather stations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include ensuring the collection of complete data sets with 1440 data points daily, handling missing data marked as -6999, removing duplicate records, discarding data that falls outside physical meaning or instrument range, and managing data gaps due to sensor failures or equipment malfunctions, as observed in the data from July 15-24 and after December 8.
